awd_titl_txt: Strings 2010  Conference held in Collge Station, TX
awd_abstract_narration: Over the past two decades, string theory has come to play a leading role within the field of theoretical high-energy physics.  It has not only provided many new insights concerning the possibilities for physics at the highest energy scales, but also led to new, deeper understandings of gauge theory, gravity, and even condensed-matter physics and nuclear (heavy-ion) physics.  This award provides support for Strings 2010, the latest in a series of highly successful annual international conferences covering all aspects of string theory, to be held at Texas A&M University. In general, speakers at the Strings conferences include most of the leading figures of the field.  NSF support of this conference will enable young researchers (graduate students and postdoctoral fellows) to attend this conference at reduced expense.  This will enable them to keep abreast of current developments in the field, and to publicize the work that they themselves are doing to a larger audience of their peers, both senior and junior.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The NSF grant with number 0946452 was one of the sources of funding used to organize the Strings 2010 conference, which will took place in College Station, Texas, March 15-19, 2010.


This conference was organized and was held at the George P. and Cynthia W. Mitchell Institute for Fundamental Physics and Astronomy. The Mitchell Institute is part of the Physics Department at Texas A&M University, located in College Station, Texas. This was a major conference devoted to string theory, M-theory and its generalizations. It was one of the series of string conferences which has taken place annually since the end of the 1980s. (The 1989 and 1990 string conferences were also held at Texas A&M). The funding was used
to pay for the travel expenses of speakers and to have an affordable registration fee for participants, which would also be affordable for students and postdocs, who would otherwise not be able to participate. The talks were web-casted online live to allow anyone interested in the topic and owning a computer to be able to follow the talks.


More information about the conference, which includes the list of speakers and the program can be found on the conference web site at the URL: http://mitchell.physics.tamu.edu/Conference/string2010/


Last Modified: 12/21/2011
Modified by: Katrin Becker
